Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Tinkershire \Tink"er*shire\, Tinkle \Tin"kle\, n. (Zo["o]l.) The common guillemot. [Prov. Eng.] [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Tinkle \Tin"kle\, v. i. [Freq. of tink. See {Tink}, {Tingle}.] 1. To make, or give forth, small, quick, sharp sounds, as a piece of metal does when struck; to clink. [1913 Webster]
As sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal. --1 Cor. xiii. 1. [1913 Webster]
The sprightly horse Moves to the music of his tinkling bells. --Dodsley. [1913 Webster]
2. To hear, or resound with, a small, sharp sound. [1913 Webster]
And his ears tinkled, and the color fled. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Tinkle \Tin"kle\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Tinkled}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Tinkling}.] To cause to clonk, or make small, sharp, quick sounds. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Tinkle \Tin"kle\, n. A small, sharp, quick sound, as that made by striking metal. --Cowper. [1913 Webster]
tinkle n : a light clear metallic sound as of a small bell [syn: {ting}] v : make or emit a high sound; "tinkling bells" [syn: {tink}, {clink}, {chink}]
